description: This is an insult that is given instead of a reason.
name: Ad Hominem

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I don't think dyslexia is a virus, Bill.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: You didn't even graduate from college so it makes sense you would think that. It is a virus.

description: The arguer tries to inflate the worth of his argument by associating it with a well known authority who is not an actual authority on the subject at hand. The arguer may also try to use his/her own authority to persuade listeners.
name: Appeal to Authority

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I can't wait to start the semester at the prestigious Trump University. I'm on the road to the promiseland!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I don't think that school is even accredited. Isn't it more of a collection of weekend seminars inside of a hotel lobby than an actual university?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: No. It's a real university and it's a great school. Donald Trump is rich and powerful. He wouldn't put his name on the line for something that doesn't work.

description: This is really just a threat. The arguer tries to get others to adopt his/her point of view or else the arguer will cause them harm.
name: Appeal to Force

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: You better start liking Nickelback or I'll tell your wife that you cheated on her!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Okay. Okay...

description: Wherein judgment is based solely on whether the subject of judgment is "natural" or "unnatural."
name: Appeal to Nature

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Maybe you should double check with your doctor before applying that arsenic to your wound...

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's a perfectly natural substance that isn't man-made. Don't worry. It's all good.

description: When following the law is assumed to be the morally correct thing to do, without justification, or when breaking the law is assumed to be the morally wrong thing to do, without justification. This can also happen when one equates supporting the legalization of something with actually supporting it.
name: Appeal to the Law

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Last night I was seduced by a woman and ended up cheating on Katie.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Don't worry. Adultery isn't illegal.

description: This form of argument tries to persaude the listener that an idea must be true because it has been believed or practiced for a long time.
name: Appeal to Tradition

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Do you really want your daughter going into prostitution?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's the world's oldest profession. It couldn't have existed for this long if it wasn't a good profession.

description: Where something is claimed to be true or good solely because lots of others believe it to be so.
name: Bandwagoning

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Bitcoin at 20k is a steal! I'm stocking up.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Have you given this invesment much thought?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: No, but everyone else is buying right now.

description: Making a claim without offering any proof to substantiate it.
name: Baseless Claim

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: My new car gets 500 miles per gallon!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Proof?

description: Providing what is essentially the conclusion of the argument as a premise.
name: Begging the question

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why is using drugs wrong?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Because it's illegal

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why is it illegal?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Because it's wrong

description: The arguer gives the impression that there are only two extreme positions that are possible. This does not allow for moderate, middle grounds or grey areas.
name: Black or white

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: There are two kinds of people in this world: people who recognize Nickelback as the greatest band to ever exist, and people who can't appreciate good music because they're low IQ scum fucks!

description: Instead of providing evidence to support a claim, the arguer implies that it is true because his/her opponent has not proved it to be false. Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.
name: Burden of Proof

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Any plans for this weekend?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I'm going to search for that hidden treasure that's buried out in the desert that I was telling you about. Over $20 million in gold.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Are you even sure that such a thing exists?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Well, no one has been able to prove to me that isn't buried out there. Until someone does I'm just going to assume that it is.

description: The act of pointing at individual cases or data that seem to confirm a particular position, while ignoring a significant portion of related cases or data that may contradict that position.
name: Cherry Picking

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: They say that alcohol is bad for the liver but my dad started binge drinking at 14 and he never had a problem with his liver.

description: The belief that ending a cruel policy is an insult to all of the people who were previously victimized by it.
name: Don't Cut in Line

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: What Harriet Tubman did was a real insult to black people.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: How so?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: She helped black people illegally escape. It was against the law!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Yeah, but

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: But nothing! What about all the other slaves who invested their precious time waiting to be set free LEGALLY!?

description: The power of holding two contradictory beliefs in one's mind simultaneously, and accepting both of them.
name: Doublethink

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Our rights come from God and people need to stop trying to take them away.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I hear ya. The government has really trampled the rights of a lot of undocumented immigrants.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: They ain't Americans. So they don't have any rights here.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Aren't rights God given?

description: This isn't a fallacy; it's just a very cruel and dishonest tactic. This happens when someone uses a tragedy to advance their narrative or for their own personal gain. The gains can range from mere attention on social media to money or favors. This happens a lot after school shootings in the United States. Using this fallacy typically indicates a clear lack of empathy on behalf of the person employing it.
name: Exploiting Tragedies

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: That's awful what happened to Peggy. Suicide can be prevented if people have access to good mental health treatment.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Yeah, but remember what I told you about those liberals? Liberalism is a mental disorder and Peggy's death confirms that.

description: An inaccurate fact that is used to advance an argument.
name: Factual Inaccuracy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Trump's response to Hurricane Harvey may have sucked but Obama's response to Katrina in 2005 was bad too.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Pretty sure that Obama wasn't president in 2005.

description: Describes a situation of logical and apparent equivalence, when in fact there is none.
name: False Equivalence

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Guns kill way too many people each year. They should be tougher to get.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: What about cars? Many more people die each year in car accidents. Should they be tougher to get too?

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Guns are designed to kill. Cars are designed to transport people from one place to another.

description: A rhetorical tactic that asserts that if your ideas are ridiculed, then they must be valid. This fallacy earns its name from Galileo‘s famous persecution at the hands of the Catholic Church for his defense of heliocentrism in the face of the orthodox Biblical literalism of the day.
name: Galileo's Gambit

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Let me tell you about my latest startup venture. It's an iPhone app that informs users of the closest cigarette butts on the sidewalk. It's exactly like ReBag just for used cigarettes instead of used hand bags. I'm calling it ReButt.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Ha. Are you for real?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Laugh all you want. They laughed at the Wright brothers too so I know I'm in good company.

description: Discrediting the source or origin of an argument instead of the argument itself.
name: Genetic Fallacy

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Check out the article from the New York Times that I sent you. I'd like to hear your take.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It ain't real. The failing New York Times is fake news.

description: The arguer attributes a property to an entire group based only on observing that property in an individual.
name: Hasty Generalization

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: People from Salt Lake City sure are crazy. I had a roommate in college who was from there and she partied all the time.

description: An error in reasoning whereby one believes that someone or something are actually what they self-identify as despite all evidence to the contrary. Anyone can choose to identify as whatever they want to but it doesn't necessarily mean that the self-identification is accurate.
name: It's in the name!

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I sure do hope that Kim Jong Un gets impeached or voted out of power in the next election.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Elections? North Korea is a dictatorship.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Nope. The Democratic People's Republic of Korea is actually a democracy. The word 'democratic' is in the country's name, after all.

description: A question posed that implies an unstated major premise such that any answer will trap the answerer into appearing to agree with the unstated premise.
name: Loaded Question

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: You still cheat on your wife, Rob?

description: The belief that technological progress should be slowed down or even halted so jobs will not be lost.
name: Luddite Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Never use ATM's or self-checkout machines at the supermarket.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: They take jobs away from tellers and cashiers.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Should I stop using email too because that takes jobs away from the post office?

description: Assuming that the compromise between two positions is correct.
name: Middle Ground

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Scientists say that global warming is real but the guys down at the bodega say that it isn't. It's probably only half real...

description: In which one assumes a 'holier-than-thou' attitude in an attempt to make oneself look good to win an argument.
name: Moral High Ground

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: AIDS is a man made disease. Trust me, I've volunteered at an AIDS clinic for years and I've helped plenty of sick children.

description: When criteria are met that falsify the arguer's position, the arguer changes the criteria and claims that his/her position is still valid.
name: Moving the Goalposts

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: If evolution ins't real then how do humans become resistant to antibiotics?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Small amounts of evolution are possible. But, not a lot.

description: When arguing against an action or policy, this fallacy is committed if the arguer declares the action to be useless if it does not lead to ideal conditions. It is related to the false dichotomy in that it implies that if the action does not lead to perfection, then it is useless. It does not recognize that simple improvement is worthwhile. Essentially, if it isn't perfect, then it is useless.
name: Nirvana Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Why should murder be illegal? People still kill each other anyways.

description: If the premise of the argument is falsified with a counter example, rather than changing the conclusion, the arguer changes the definition of a major premise to make both the premise and the conclusion true. Typically, the arguer makes a sweeping generalization about an entire group. This is usually done by implying that the group is bound and defined by the arbitrary quality. If an exception to this generalization is pointed out, the arguer dismisses the exception as not truly belonging to the group in the first place.
name: No True Scotsman

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It is the duty of police officers to protect and serve with honesty and integrity. They would never break the law.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Really? Hundreds of cops get busted each and every year for corruption and brutality.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: They aren't real cops.

description: A conclusion or statement that does not logically follow from the previous argument or statement.
name: Non Sequitur

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Brush your teeth every morning. Help fight injustice.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: What?

description: A precedes B, therefore A caused B.
name: Post Hoc Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's a miracle! Just one day after I asked god to heal my sore throat it went away!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Are you sure that it didn't have anything to do with visiting the doctor?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Nope. It was god!

description: A type of non-sequitir whereby one asserts that if a certain group of people are statistically over/under represented in something, that discrimination and/or bigotry is the culprit.
name: Quota Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's super messed up that more than 80% of the people who are convicted of insider trading are white men. The SEC is racist against white men.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Are you sure that's the reason?

description: A speaker attempts to distract an audience by deviating from the topic at hand by introducing a separate argument the speaker believes is easier to speak to.
name: Red Herring

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: It's wrong to steal from your neighbors. Don't you think you should stop it already?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: But, who defines what is moral?

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: As humans, we have an innate sense of morality that's built into all of us with the exception of psychopaths.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Medication may help people with mental illness develop a sense of morality.

description: Conspiracy theory style reasoning wherein an argument is dismissed because the person who is putting it forth is assumed be profiting from the position that they're taking. This can also be an ad hominem attack. It's common for the person whose argument has been dismissed to be accused of being on a company's payroll. This assumes that the only legitimate reason one can have for taking a certain position is personal gain.
name: Shill Gambit

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Man! My head is killing me!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Take a couple of aspirin pills. That should help.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Ha! So you can collect some more dividends from Bayer?

description: The arguer tries to convince others that one action will lead to a series of events that will eventually lead to an ultimate, usually unwanted, consequence. This is fallacious if it is unlikely that each intermediate step will necessarily follow the preceding one.
name: Slippery Slope

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Gays shouldn't be allowed to get married!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why not?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: We've gotta draw the line somewhere. Before you know it, people will be given the right to marry children. Then their pets. And before you know it, they'll be marrying their cars.

description: The arguer attempts to explain a discrepancy in his/her argument by assigning special properties to his/her position that immunizes it from criticism. Special Pleading may render a claim unfalsifiable. The fallacy of Special Pleading occurs when someone argues that a case is an exception to a rule based upon an irrelevant characteristic that does not define an exception. Special Pleading also may occur when the arguer implies that opponents of his/her point of view cannot possibly understand it because they lack the capacity or skills needed to comprehend it.
name: Special Pleading

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: You're totally wrong about that quote by Abraham Lincoln about not believing everything you read on the internet. That quote isn't real.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: There isn't any universal truth. Each person has their own version of the what's true.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: ...and you believe that to be true?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Yep

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I thought that nothing was universally true?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Well... except for that.

description: Giving the impression of refuting an opponent's argument, while actually refuting an argument that was not advanced by that opponent.
name: Strawman

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: The military receives way too much of the budget.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: So you want America to be invaded by a foriegn country and citizens like us to be kept as hostages?

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Did I say that?

description: The mistaken belief that a random event must be due to happen soon if it has not happened in an unusually long time.
name: The Gambler's Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I'm gonna order a new jacket just so I'm prepared for the blizzard that's header our way.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: We're in Miami. It doesn't even snow here.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: My point exactly. It hasn't snowed here in so long that we're long overdue for a snow storm. Any day now...

description: Cherry picking data that supports your contention while ignoring data that contradcits it. Basically, confirmation bias.
name: The Texas Sharpshooter

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: My fortune teller told me that something positive was in my future in the form of a white piece of paper. Today, I received a letter in the mail telling me that all the charges against me have been dropped! She knows her stuff!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Yeah... but she also talked about a million other things.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: So what!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: If you make enough predictions, then sooner or later some of them will probably become true. But, that's because of pure luck; not any uncanny ability to predict the future with accuracy.

description: A commonly used phrase, sometimes passing as folk wisdom, used to quell cognitive dissonance, conceal lack of thought-entertainment, move on to other topics.
name: Thought Terminating Cliché

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I can usually tolerate a lot, but your religious rituals are starting to affect me.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's a relationship; not a religion.

description: A type of non-sequitir whereby one attempts to take credit for the deeds of someone else who belongs to the same group of people as the person putting forth the argument.
name: Tribal Fallacy

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I saw on your LinkedIn profile that you listed the creation of Facebook as one of your accomplishments. What's up with that?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Well, Mark and I have both worked as programmers.

description: This is an attack on the circumstances of the arguer. May imply ulterior motives or conflict of interests.
name: Tu Quoque

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Rob says that cigarettes cause lung cancer but he smokes a pack a day. Smoking doesn't cause cancer!

description: When a person attempts to justify an action against another person because the other person did take or would take the same action against him or her.
name: Two Wrongs Make a Right

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Did you contact the person whose ID was in that wallet that you found last night?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I'm not gonna return it.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why not?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: They would never contact me if they had found my wallet.

description: A claim that is asserted that cannot be proven wrong. No evidence suffices as valid evidence.
name: Unfalsifiable Claim

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: The leprechaun that's living in my closet is beginning to become a real pain in the ass.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I don't see any leprechaun in your closet.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It's only visible to me and no one else.

description: This happens when someone changes the definition of a word in such a way that reality conforms to their biases or lies.
name: Word Redefinition

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: I think it's really messed up that you stole our neighbor's car a few nights ago.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: It wasn't stealing. My definition of stealing is when you take something that belongs to someone else without their permission and have no plan of returning it. I was going to return her car until I crashed it.

description: A deflection tactic that is used to shift the focus of attention away from what is being criticized on to other stuff that is totally irrelevant.
name: Whataboutism

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: What's going on in Venezuela right now is awful.

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: But, what about what's going on right here in America?

description: This isn't any sort of coherent argument or rhetoric. However, it often masquerades as one if the person communicating it is well spoken. This is essentially just a confused or unintelligible mixture of seemingly random words and phrases.
name: Word Salad

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: Orderliness imparts reality to a symbolic representation of acceptance.

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: What?

description: When one assumes that someone else’s gain is a loss to other players; and the total amount of the available money or resources is fixed. A logical fallacy often occurs when this particular game theory is applied to economic or political discussions amongst non-economists – leading to false beliefs that the amount of wealth or jobs in the economy is fixed.
name: Zero Sum Fallacy

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: I hope that you lose your job soon!

dialogue.name: Rational Rob
dialogue.message: Why? What did I do to you?

dialogue.name: Blathering Bill
dialogue.message: You having a job and having more money than me means that I have less money, you greedy bastard.
